questions.q: What is an operating system?
questions.explanation: The OS manages hardware resources and provides a platform for applications to run.
options: A program that acts as an intermediary between a user and computer hardware

questions.q: Goals of an operating system include:
questions.explanation: An OS balances user convenience with the efficient allocation of system resources.
options: Making the system convenient to use

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT a component of a computer system?
questions.explanation: While used to create software, a programming language is a tool rather than a core functional component of the system architecture.

questions.q: Which program loads at system startup?
questions.explanation: The bootstrap program is stored in ROM or EEPROM and initializes the system to load the kernel.

questions.q: Interrupts are used to signal:
questions.explanation: Interrupts are the primary mechanism for hardware or software to gain the CPU's attention for various events.

questions.q: Which storage is the fastest?
questions.explanation: Registers are located inside the CPU and provide the highest speed access to data.

questions.q: The purpose of caching is to:
questions.explanation: Caching stores frequently used data in faster memory to reduce the time spent fetching it from slower storage.

questions.q: In a multiprocessor system, which is NOT an advantage?
questions.explanation: Multiprocessor systems often increase programming complexity due to synchronization and task distribution requirements.

questions.q: What is the difference between concurrency and parallelism?
questions.explanation: Concurrency supports more than one task by switching between them, while parallelism performs multiple tasks simultaneously.
options: Concurrency is multiple tasks at the same time; parallelism is one task at a time
Concurrency is on a single core; parallelism is on multiple cores
Concurrency is for I/O; parallelism is for CPU

questions.q: What does DMA stand for?
questions.explanation: DMA allows I/O devices to transmit data directly to/from memory without constant CPU intervention.

questions.q: Which is a non-volatile storage device?
questions.explanation: Non-volatile storage like a hard disk retains its data even when the power is turned off.

questions.q: What is the role of the kernel?
questions.explanation: The kernel is the one program running at all times on the computer, managing all hardware and software interactions.
options: Act as the core part of the OS, always running

questions.q: Which of the following is a real-time operating system use case?
questions.explanation: Real-time systems must process data and respond within strict time constraints, which is critical for safety systems like cars.

questions.q: In which OS structure are jobs kept in memory to maximize CPU usage?
questions.explanation: Multiprogramming ensures the CPU always has a job to execute by keeping several jobs in memory simultaneously.

questions.q: What is a trap in OS terminology?
questions.explanation: A trap (or exception) is caused by an error (like division by zero) or a specific request from a user program for OS service.

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT a storage management activity?
questions.explanation: Process synchronization is a part of process management, not storage or disk management.

questions.q: What is the purpose of dual-mode operation?
questions.explanation: User mode and Kernel mode ensure that user programs cannot directly access hardware or critical OS memory.
options: To protect the OS from user programs

questions.q: Which computing environment uses 'thin clients'?
questions.explanation: Thin clients rely on a central server for processing, common in distributed and network-based environments.

questions.q: What does open-source mean?
questions.explanation: Open-source software provides its source code to the public for use, modification, and distribution.

questions.q: Which is an example of a cloud service model?
questions.explanation: Software as a Service, Platform as a Service, and Infrastructure as a Service are the three main cloud pillars.

questions.q: What is a process?
questions.explanation: A program is a passive entity (file), while a process is an active entity currently running in memory.

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT part of a process in memory?
questions.explanation: The text, stack, heap, and data sections reside in RAM; the hard disk is external storage.

questions.q: What does PCB stand for?
questions.explanation: The PCB stores all the information needed by the OS to manage a specific process.

questions.q: Which state indicates a process is waiting for an event?
questions.explanation: The 'Waiting' state occurs when a process cannot proceed until an I/O completion or signal occurs.

questions.q: What is the role of the long-term scheduler?
questions.explanation: The long-term scheduler (job scheduler) selects processes from a pool and loads them into memory for execution.
options: Selects which process runs next on CPU

questions.q: What is context switching?
questions.explanation: Context switching involves saving the state of the current process and loading the saved state of another process.
options: Changing CPU from one process to another

questions.q: Which system call creates a new process in UNIX?
questions.explanation: The fork() system call creates a nearly identical copy of the calling process.

questions.q: A process that has finished but still has an entry in the process table is called:
questions.explanation: A zombie process has terminated, but its exit status hasn't been read by its parent yet.

questions.q: What is interprocess communication (IPC)?
questions.explanation: IPC provides mechanisms for processes to communicate and synchronize their actions.

questions.q: Which IPC method uses a shared memory region?
questions.explanation: Shared memory allows multiple processes to read and write to the same block of RAM for high-speed communication.

questions.q: In the producer-consumer problem, a bounded buffer:
questions.explanation: A bounded buffer has a specific capacity; the producer must wait if the buffer is full.
options: Is used only by the producer

questions.q: Which of the following is a message-passing primitive?
questions.explanation: Message passing relies on explicit send and receive operations to transfer data between processes.

questions.q: What is a socket?
questions.explanation: A socket is defined by an IP address concatenated with a port number.

questions.q: What is RPC?
questions.explanation: RPC allows a program to cause a procedure to execute in another address space (usually on another computer).

questions.q: Which pipe requires a parent-child relationship?
questions.explanation: Ordinary pipes are anonymous and can only be used by processes that share a common ancestor.

questions.q: In process termination, what does abort() do?
questions.explanation: A parent may abort a child if the child has exceeded its allocated resources or is no longer needed.

questions.q: What is a thread within a process?
questions.explanation: Threads allow a single process to perform multiple tasks concurrently while sharing the same memory space.
options: A lightweight unit of CPU utilization

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT a reason for process cooperation?
questions.explanation: Cooperation aims to improve efficiency and modularity; security risks are a potential disadvantage, not a goal.

questions.q: What is a rendezvous in IPC?
questions.explanation: A rendezvous occurs in synchronous message passing when the sender and receiver both wait for each other.
options: When both send and receive are blocking
When a process is in waiting state
When a process creates a child

questions.q: Which of the following is an example of indirect communication?
questions.explanation: In indirect communication, messages are sent to and received from mailboxes or ports.

questions.q: What is a thread?
questions.explanation: A thread is the basic unit of CPU utilization, comprising a thread ID, program counter, register set, and stack.
options: A lightweight process within a process

questions.q: Which of the following is a benefit of multithreading?
questions.explanation: Multithreading allows applications to remain responsive, share memory easily, and save time on context switches.

questions.q: What is the difference between parallelism and concurrency?
questions.explanation: Parallelism actually performs tasks at the same time on different cores; concurrency creates the illusion of simultaneity.
options: Parallelism runs tasks simultaneously; concurrency interleaves tasks
Parallelism is only for single-core systems

questions.q: What does Amdahl's Law predict?
questions.explanation: It calculates the potential speedup of a program when using multiple processors based on its serial and parallel parts.

questions.q: Which threading model maps many user threads to one kernel thread?
questions.explanation: The Many-to-One model handles all thread management in user space, but one blocking call blocks the whole process.

questions.q: Which OS uses the One-to-One threading model?
questions.explanation: Most modern operating systems, including Windows and Linux, use the One-to-One model.

questions.q: What is Pthreads?
questions.explanation: Pthreads is a POSIX standard (IEEE 1003.1c) defining an API for thread creation and synchronization.

questions.q: Which function creates a thread in Pthreads?
questions.explanation: The pthread_create function is used to start a new thread of execution within a process.

questions.q: What is thread cancellation?
questions.explanation: Cancellation is the task of terminating a thread before it has completed its work.

questions.q: What does TLS stand for?
questions.explanation: TLS allows each thread to have its own private copy of certain data.

questions.q: Which of the following is an implicit threading method?
questions.explanation: Implicit threading transfers the burden of thread management from the programmer to the compiler or runtime library.

questions.q: What is a thread pool?
questions.explanation: Thread pools prevent the overhead of frequent thread creation and destruction by reusing existing threads.
options: A group of pre-created threads waiting for work

questions.q: OpenMP is used for:
questions.explanation: OpenMP uses compiler directives to identify parallel regions in C, C++, or Fortran code.

questions.q: Grand Central Dispatch is associated with:
questions.explanation: GCD is a technology developed by Apple for macOS and iOS to manage parallel tasks.

questions.q: Which of the following is a threading issue?
questions.explanation: Designers must consider how signals are delivered to multithreaded processes and how shared data is managed.

questions.q: In multithreading, what does fork() do?
questions.explanation: Some UNIX systems have two versions of fork: one that duplicates all threads and one that only duplicates the calling thread.

questions.q: What is an LWP?
questions.explanation: An LWP is a data structure between user and kernel threads that appears as a virtual processor.

questions.q: Which Windows data structure stores thread ID and user stack?
questions.explanation: The Thread Environment Block (TEB) is a user-space structure containing thread-specific information.

questions.q: In Linux, which system call creates threads?
questions.explanation: The clone() system call allows the child to share the address space of the parent, effectively creating a thread.

questions.q: What is the main advantage of multithreaded server architecture?
questions.explanation: A multithreaded server can handle a new request in a separate thread without making other clients wait.
